thread.title: Bournemouth 0-2 Crystal Palace: Dann & Benteke Finally Give Allardyce 1st League Win as Eagles Boss
thread.title_full: Bournemouth 0-2 Crystal Palace: Dann & Benteke Finally Give Allardyce 1st League Win as Eagles Boss | 90min

author: Crystal Palace
title: Bournemouth 0-2 Crystal Palace: Dann & Benteke Finally Give Allardyce 1st League Win as Eagles Boss
text:
​Second half strikes from Scott Dann and Christian Benteke proved enough to help Crystal Palace to a vital 2-0 win over Bournemouth and finally give new manager Sam Allardyce his first league win. Having failed to taste victory in the Premier League since early December, the Eagles ran out worthy winners on the south coast as Dann, who continues to be a thorn in the Cherries' side having scored in the two previous meetings between the teams, and Benteke breathed new life into Palace's campaign and offered them renewed hope that they can beat the drop. Both managers made a couple of changes to their respective lineups for the clash at what was a wet and windy Vitality stadium. Cherries skipper Simon Francis returned to the heart of the hosts' defence, whilst Benik Afobe was preferred to Callum Wilson as the lone striker. The Eagles meanwhile were pleased to welcome back Wilfried Zaha from the Africa Cup of Nations. New signing Patrick Van Aanholt also came into the side to make his debut and lined up at left wing-back as Allardyce opted to trial a 3-4-3 formation. Despite their recent poor form, it was the visitors who made the brighter start to the match as the returning Zaha caused an early moment of panic for Bournemouth when his 20-yard effort cannoned off the base of Artur Boruc's post. The home side continued to look uncomfortable for much of the early exchanges, particularly from set pieces, and it took until the 21st minute for Joshua King to have their first real effort on goal when his long range strike flew inches wide. PHOTOS: A few tackles flying in in the middle of the park! #BOUCRY pic.twitter.com/3y5CMXuair — Crystal Palace F.C. (@CPFC) January 31, 2017 The rest of the first half was a fairly scrappy affair as both sides struggled to keep possession in the middle of the pitch. Junior Stanislas arguably had the Cherries' best chance but saw his left footed effort deflect narrowly wide, whilst at the other end, the lively Zaha forced a fine reaction save from Boruc, having somehow found space inside a crowded penalty area.  The first half of our @premierleague game against @CPFC in numbers... #BOUCRY pic.twitter.com/URCiUaDXCZ — AFC Bournemouth  (@afcbournemouth) January 31, 2017 ​​After a relatively drab opening 45 minutes, the second half burst into life as the Eagles took the lead just moments after kick off. Jason Puncheon's cross from the left hand side was flicked into the path of Dann, via Damien Delaney's head, and the Palace skipper kept his cool to place the ball into the bottom corner. Buoyed by their goal, the away side pressed for a second and they would have found one had Van Aanholt not lost his composure when through on goal. The Dutchman was nearly made to pay for his wastefulness when King headed onto the top of Wayne Hennessey's net as the game finally started to open up.  No way through at the moment... #BOUCRY pic.twitter.com/cl8F9MvfUr — AFC Bournemouth  (@afcbournemouth) January 31, 2017 Eddie Howe made a number of changes just after the hour mark as his side went in search of the equaliser, however a resilient Palace defence only allowed their opponents shots from distance and were grateful that Francis was unable to convert a cross at the back post. The game became fragmented as it reached the closing stages but in truth, despite their best efforts, Bournemouth failed to really test Hennessey until stoppage time when Jack Wilshere's low shot struck the post. With time all but up, Francis' mistake allowed substitute Andros Townsend to run down the wing and cross for the unmarked Christian Benteke who powered home a header to finally end Palace's eight-match winless run in the Premier League, not to mention his own personal goal drought. Whilst the three points will come as a welcome relief to Allardyce and his men, they remain in the relegation zone after Swansea beat Southamtpon 2-1 at the Liberty stadium. For Bournemouth meanwhile, their poor form continues and Tuesday's defeat means they are still yet to win a match in 2017. THAT'S IT! @afcbournemouth 0-2 Palace! A win, a clean sheet! What a performance from the Eagles. — Crystal Palace F.C. (@CPFC) January 31, 2017  Three changes for the Cherries as they host @CPFC in the @premierleague . #BOUCRY #afcb  pic.twitter.com/IZBwDVN0WW — AFC Bournemouth  (@afcbournemouth) January 31, 2017 Here is your #CPFC team for tonight's game against @afcbournemouth : pic.twitter.com/Zplm7UvVz2 — Crystal Palace F.C. (@CPFC) January 31, 2017

Andy Carroll (Newcastle United to Liverpool for £35m 2011)

Christopher Samba (Anzhi Makhachkala to QPR for £12.5m 2013)

Fernando Torres (Liverpool to Chelsea for £50m 2011)

Jean-Alain Boumsong (Rangers to Newcastle United for £8.3m 2005)

Konstantinos Mitroglou (Olympiakos to Fulham for £12m 2014)

Savio Nsereko (Brescia to West Ham United for £9m 2009)
